Course Section Definition Public Notes:
Delivery Mode -This is a synchronous multi-access course. Students are expected to meet on the days and times listed, either in-person or online. All courses labelled ‘multi-access’ offer students the choice of completing the course online, in-person, or using a mix of both. In-person attendance is NOT required, but the option to attend in-person is available. Lectures may be streamed from a classroom and/or uploaded online after class.

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to “Waitlist” and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

Course Section Definition Public Notes:
This section of PHIL 101 will only involve full class meetings (no discussion section meetings). To register, students must also register for PHIL101.L07, but this “discussion section” will not involve additional scheduled meetings.
Course Description: Overview of Western philosophers, focusing on the five most influential Western philosophers of all time: Plato, Aristotle, Descartes, Hume, and Kant. Their impact on contemporary philosophy is also studied.

This section of PHIL 101 will only involve full class meetings (no discussion section meetings). To register, students must also register for PHIL101.L07, but this “discussion section” will not involve additional scheduled meetings.

Dr. Margolis' PHIL101 will be taught using a hybrid method of delivery. Part of the course will be in person and part will be prerecorded lectures.
A general statement about Dr. Margolis' PHIL101: https://www.margolisphilosophy.com/phil101-blurb.html
FAQs about Dr. Margolis' PHIL101: https://www.margolisphilosophy.com/101-faq.html
This discussion section, which does not involve additional scheduled meetings, is for students registered in PHIL101.004 or PHIL101.005.

This course is part of the Coordinated Arts Program, Political Science, Philosophy and Economics stream, https://cap.arts.ubc.ca/streams/political-science-philosophy-economics-ppe/. 
Students must register in both Term 1 and Term 2 courses in CAP. 
Follow the prompts to register in all stream seminars (1), lectures (2), and tutorials (1-2) each term. 
For step-by-step instructions, please visit: https://cap.arts.ubc.ca/program/registration/ 
If you encounter any issues with registration into CAP, please contact us at support.fyip@ubc.ca  

This section of PHIL 102 will only involve full class meetings (no discussion section meetings). To register, students must also register for PHIL102.L07, but this “discussion section” will not involve additional scheduled meetings.

Please note: PHIL 101 and PHIL 102 are independent introductory courses and do not need to be taken in sequential order.

This section of PHIL 102 will only involve full class meetings (no discussion section meetings). To register, students must also register for PHIL102.L07, but this “discussion section” will not involve additional scheduled meetings.

Please note: PHIL 101 and PHIL 102 are independent introductory courses and do not need to be taken in sequential order.

PHIL102 section 004 is one of the Place and Power courses approved for the 2024/25 academic year. (re: BA requirements for students who enter the program in 2024/25 or later)

Course Description: This course takes place on the traditional, ancestral, and unceded territory of the xʷməθkʷəýəm (Musqueam) People. All sections of PHIL 102 address basic problems and methods of philosophy. This section covers topics in ethics, epistemology, political philosophy, and aestheticsrelating to local Indigenous societies in the context of settler colonialism. The course adopts a primary focus on Musqueam, extending its view outwards to Squamish and Tsleil-Waututh, as well as to the rest of BC and beyond. The principal areas addressed are: (1) The philosophy of art and storytelling, with emphases on: Relationships between art and power, Cultural appropriation, Stereotyping and reclamation, and Story-based knowledge; (2) Epistemologies of knowledge and ignorance; (3) Environmental ethics; and (4) Philosophies of power and oppression, in particular as applied to: The marginalization of Indigenous peoples under Canadian colonialism, Anti-Indigenous structural racism in North American contexts, and UBC’s past and present position within the colonial power structure.

PHIL102.005 has mandatory discussion sections. Students are required to register in one of the following discussion sections: L01, L02, L03, L04, or L05.

Please note: PHIL 101 and PHIL 102 are independent introductory courses and do not need to be taken in sequential order.
